results.title: Animated genesis (TEFC)
results.brief_description: An allegory of the creation of the world, of man’s enslavement by the machine, motivated by Greed, which is personified as an enormous and menacing spider. It is eventually overthrown by the intervention of Goodness, but not before atomic warfare has resulted. The Foldes made the film at home, drawing all 32,000 pictures, and showed the 16mm result to Sir Alexander Korda, who had it blown up to 35mm for theatrical release. No other credits available.

results.title: Animated cartoons: the toy that grew up
results.creator_credit: Roger Leenhardt and Les Films du Compas
results.brief_description: The Toy that Grew Up is a study of the antecedents of cinema, dealing mainly with the developments which took place between 1800 and 1900. The invention of a child’s toy, called a traumatrope, led Belgian physicist Joseph Plateau to study a characteristic of the human eye called persistence of vision. He established that the retina of the eye retains an impression of a luminous object a full third of a second after the actual light source has disappeared. Plateau used this scientific fact as the basis for his invention of a machine which seemed to animate static drawings. Emile Reynaud perfected Plateau’s machine, inventing a machine called the Praxinoscope, which enabled him to show animated cartoons, and later to give theatrical performances, his cartoon shows lasting as long as a quarter of an hour.

results.title: Animated
results.brief_description: An off-the-wall, engagingly funny, slightly serious and brilliantly assembled collection of the maddest moments of Australia’s unsung film art. A film which rolls 75 years of history into 80 rip roaring minutes of fun and hi-jinx.

results.title: Animals: ways they move
results.brief_description: Illustrates how animals move in water, on land and in the air. Explains that an animal’s movement helps it to acquire food, to protect itself from enemies, to find a home, to move from place to place, and to adapt to its environment.

results.title: Animals: ways they eat
results.creator_credit: William A. Anderson and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows how the body parts of various animals are related to their eating habits. Includes such examples as the cirri or barnacles, the mouth parts and legs of crayfish, the teeth of lions and cows, the tongues of butterflies, the noses of hogs, the beaks of birds, and the paws of squirrels.

results.title: Animals: friends or food? [Widescreen] (D)
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Jason Young and Kent Martin
results.brief_description: A would-be farmer, Jason Young, and his partner take on an abandoned farm property, with the view to running a small hobby-farm, and horse-riding school. Whilst Julia attends to the horse-business Jason decides to experiment with raising an array of animals with a view to eating them, in order to bring himself closer to the processes of animal husbandry that so many have become immune to. Thus begins Jason’s year of discovery as he buys, bonds, feeds, tends and lovingly breeds the animals. At certain points when Jason is called upon to slaughter the animals he confronts the issues around meat eating, and is moved by the bonds he has formed with the various breeds. Although at times simplistic, this documentary nevertheless teases out the issues of the meat consumer industry, human-animal relationships and the ethical treatment of animals. Contains scenes of animal slaughter. Please note: some scenes may disturb.

results.title: Animals without backbones
results.brief_description: What kinds of structures do these animals have? How do such bodies move about? How are their bodies supported? Nature photography points out the characteristics of the anthropods, spiny-skinned animals, molluscs, sponges, bag-like animals, and earthworms, and shows these animals carrying out some of their life functions.

results.title: Animals that build
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Society and Sidney Platt
results.brief_description: This film focuses on animals as engineers, constructing elaborate dwellings and protection devices. From tiny microscopic creatures like coral, insects like spiders and caterpillars through to birds and mammals like beavers and man, the program provides a useful insight into the natural world. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
